div1.head: Letter from Adrian Macia to Philip Showalter Hench, January 6, 1941
div1.opener:
CORRESPONDENTS OF
J. J. WINDLE & CO., INC., NEW YORK
AND
TOPLIS AND HARDING, INCORPORATED
----
TELEPHONES
M-8605 - A-7730
----
CABLE ADDRESSES
WINDLE - HAVANA
TOPLIS - HAVANA
ADRIAN MACIA
INGENIERO CIVIL Y ARQUITECTO
MANZANA DE GOMEZ 325
HAVANA, CUBA
January 6, 1941
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Dr. Hench.:
div1.p:
I am very sorry that I have not been able to answer your
letters until now, but I have been extremely busy at the end of the year,
and have been out of town lately for several days. I am sending this by
Airmail, today, in the hope that you will still be at Rochester or that
it will be forwarded to you.

I will now answer your questions in the letter of November
21, 1941.

In regards to the first question I want to inform you that
the 150 square yards of land would cost about $150.00, but I hope to
arrange with my partners to make you a present of it in case your project
goes ahead.

As to the second question, nothing has been done to the
house since you saw it.

With your third question, about the taxes, I think there
will be no question of them, but if there are taxes they will be very
small.

I think that what you propose in your fourth question will
cost about $20,000.00 or more, on account of presente conditions and high
cost of materials, etc. Of course this is a very rough estimate. I cannot
give you any idea as to cost of maintenance, but if you come to some agreement
with the Cuban Government, they would probably take care of the maintenance.

In regards to the fifth question, the house will have to be
rebuilt with the same materials as much as possible, and it would probably
cost about $150.00.

On the sixth question I cannot give you any idea, but it
would probably be better to send what you want from the States.

I than you very much for the booklets you sent me, and
wishing you a very happy New Year, I remain
